awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Comparing Multi-Scalar Claims for Redress and Reparation
awd_abstract_narration:
In the second half of the twentieth century, claims for redress for historical injustices have put increasing pressure on political and legal systems. This pressure is compounded by the fact that claims for reparations may occur simultaneously at international and national levels. The research supported by this award asks how international claims for redress converge on or diverge from national claims for redress from local governments.  With this dual focus, findings from this research can be used in the development of national government and international organization strategies for engaging with the increasing growth of claims for redress. 

Columbia University anthropology doctoral student, Anna Schirrer, supervised by Dr. David Scott, will carry out the research in Guyana. Guyana is an appropriate site for the research because there are active claims for redress at multiple levels that can be leveraged for research, and because the comparatively small size of the country makes the factors involved easier to isolate for a scientific study. Currently, there are two sorts of claims at stake. One claim, articulated by the multi-state Caribbean Community organization CARICOM, is a state-driven and internationally oriented claim for redress. The other, is a national rights-based claim for land addressed by local groups to the nation-state itself. Through twelve months of ethnographic research, the researcher will compare the legal resources, ethnic identity politics, and alliance networks used to legitimize authority in making redress claims. Data will be gathered through semi-structured interviews, ego-centered network mapping, and participant observation with a non-probability sample of experts at five different nodes in these networks. This research will contribute to social science theorization of the interactions between national and cross-national socio-legal processes. To reach non-academic audiences, the Co-PI will disseminate her research findings through public presentations at NGO-academic policy forums and with local stakeholders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award enabled Columbia University anthropology doctoral candidate, Anna Schirrer, supervised by Dr. David Scott to successfully conduct fieldwork for her dissertation project entitled ?Comparing Multi-Scalar Claims for Redress and Reparation?. In recent years, demands for historical justice have intensified in several national contexts in the form of claims to right the historical wrongs of European colonialism and the transatlantic slave trade through reparations. These demands have primarily been met with skepticism and distrust from national governments and several sections of civil society. Scholars dealing with questions of reparatory justice have tended to sympathize with the moral sentiments surrounding symbolic practices of reparations, but have often assumed the impossibility of widespread material reparations in the context of colonialism and transatlantic slavery. This project was designed to investigate the material complexities of reparation claims. The fieldwork focused on the legal resources used by both governmental and non-governmental organizations to raise international claims for redress as well as national claims to customary ancestral land tenure in Guyana. The research included comparative, mixed-methods data collection including participant-observation across organizational scales and interviews with government officials, legal advisors, policymakers, and local activists. It also entailed observation and documentation of public events including activist meetings, public gatherings, memorial ceremonies as well as panels and seminars and outreach programs and the collection of published archival materials. The data collected covered topics such as official and public perceptions of policy measures related to ethnic identity politics, reparations, and land rights. While conducting research, the Co-PI also contributed to building local research capacities by assisting in grant writing initiatives.

The results of the research indicate converging ideologies of reparations for historical justice across multiple organizational and civil society scales as well as diverging perceptions about their material implications. This means that while organizations and local activist groups may share moral convictions about reparatory justice, perceptions about material redress and its application diverge. This divergence can be seen for example in claims that traverse jurisdictions in national and international courts.

The data produced from this project is being used to write the Co-PI's dissertation, scheduled to be completed by May 2022. Through international academic conference participation, the Co-PI has presented their research to both academic and civil society audiences. The Co-PI has also published their findings in peer-reviewed journals focusing on anthropology, international law, and human rights issues and organized a two-day conference at Columbia University scheduled for the spring of 2021 entitled "On the Possibility and Impossibility of Reparations for Colonialism and Slavery" that is open to the public. The idea for this conference developed from questions that emerged during the fieldwork. Furthermore, the Co-PI has developed an open-access online series showcasing her research in conversation with international scholars working on similar issues.
